subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... Paul, you are reading at the level of a 6 year old.  If we followed your argument, you would still be spelling out all the syllables of this communication.
messageBody:
On 07/12/2007, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>

>
> I can't see the problem here…. In all cases, the /3/ is unstressed.  As
> such the actual pronunciation of the vowel is less important.  You must
> bear in mind that as a novice reader you are having to spell out the
> word mentally in order to understand it.  In time you will get to
> recognise whole words as you do in TO.  Then the problem disappears!
>
>

As I have said before, this ambiguity causes me to have to re-read
words. It is true that with practice I could overcome this ambiguity,
but aren't we just repeating a flaw that exists in TO, of needing word
recognition and context to decipher a phoneme?

Paul


Paul, you are reading at the level of a 6 year old.  If we followed your argument, you would still be spelling out all the syllables of this communication.  But I bet that you read the whole thing complete word or even words at a time.

With practice you, and the rest of the world, will read QS the same way.

Think on't.

Moira
